metadata.synopsis: Volo's dialog after the goblin hunt celebration party. Occurs whether tieflings or raiders win, with a variation for whether we've met Volo or not. This is his fallback in being added to our camp.In the tiefling victory variation, Volo is sitting at his desk and thinking/writing an account of our victory that day. As we approach he should set down his pen and turn to speak with us, only returning to work again once he's dismissed us.In the goblin victory celebration, Volo is standing in a cage much like the one in which he is placed in the goblin camp. In this case, he does not wish to be freed. He isn't writing anything or holding anything, but hands off his notes off-screen if intimidated into doing so.

3.speaker: Volo
3.text: Quite a display that was - usually I'm the one providing the drama on nights such as these.
3.context: NodeContext: Laden with schadenfreude - we just had a public dalliance with a woman he considers psychotic, and she very nearly killed us afterwards.

42.speaker: Volo
42.text: I do hope you didn't catch anything. I'm sure an itching conscience is quite enough.
42.context: NodeContext: Very clearly false concern - he considers us scum for allying with this woman in the first place, and thinks we deserve whatever we get

91.speaker: Volo
91.text: What a fun friend you've made.
91.context: NodeContext: Falsely congratulatory. - he considers us scum for allying with this woman in the first place, and thinks we deserve whatever we get

41.speaker: Volo
41.text: You should get some rest. You've had such a big day.
41.context: NodeContext: Falsely congratulatory - we've committed an atrocity in his eyes and have forced him to be at the celebration.

55.speaker: Volo
55.text: See your guests aren't bored. The last thing we want is for them to make their own fun.

57.speaker: Volo
57.text: Ah, the guest of honour arrives! I've been observing the festivities from a sensible distance.

49.speaker: Volo
49.text: Volothamp Geddarm - realm-renowned author, auteur and now, it appears, very much your captive.

60.speaker: Volo
60.text: I'd heard tell of a goblin camp that had been overtaken by some new upstart god.

75.speaker: Volo
75.text: When I came to investigate, they invited me to stay. Rather permanently.

18.speaker: Volo
18.text: It seems that following one story has tipped me head-long into another - yours. And I truly can't wait to write it.

84.speaker: Player
84.text: Don't you want to join in the celebrations?

10.speaker: Volo
10.text: My friend, I am engaged in celebration in its purest form - commemoration.

0.speaker: Volo
0.text: I'm writing an account of your glorious victory.

78.speaker: Volo
78.text: What you did at the grove... I rather think the world should remember, don't you?
78.context: NodeContext: Volo thinks the player is a real villain. This should have the weight of 'don't you want your atrocities recorded?'

106.speaker: Volo
106.text: Your modesty does you credit, my fine friend. But bards and biographers need sordid details.

92.speaker: Volo
92.text: The grove, for example. Its destruction was quite necessary to your purpose, I have no doubt.

51.speaker: Volo
51.text: It's simply that, for the life of me, I cannot imagine what that purpose was. Could you elaborate?
51.context: NodeContext: Innocently asking the player why they have committed a mass killing of innocent civlians - as if idly curious

104.speaker: Player
104.text: The world will know my name. I don't need you for that.

96.speaker: Volo
96.text: I have no doubt! But such grand deeds as yours often require... interpretation. The grove, for example.

71.speaker: Volo
71.text: The unenlightened might see your actions there as no more than aimless slaughter.
71.context: NodeContext: Volo is laying it on thick. He hates you but wants the scoop so he's playing devil's advocate

32.speaker: Volo
32.text: I know you had a purpose. Though I'll grant that I'm quite in the dark as to what it was. Might you elaborate?
32.context: NodeContext: Innocently asking the player why they have committed a mass killing of innocent civlians - as if idly curious

80.speaker: Player
80.text: I don't need to justify myself to you.

88.speaker: Volo
88.text: Of course not! I am only here to bear witness.

70.speaker: Volo
70.text: It is for Kelemvor to judge you, when the time comes. May he do so justly.
70.context: NodeContext: Kelemvor is the god of the afterlife - being judged justly is not something the player would enjoy, in Volo's opinion

6.speaker: Player
6.text: I need the goblins to believe I'm on their side.

33.speaker: Volo
33.text: Ah, a ruse! You've played the part admirably, if I may say so.
33.context: NodeContext: Voice lowered; he's in on the secret.

47.speaker: Volo
47.text: These beasts appear quite convinced that you're a comrade in arms. Just as the tieflings were, I expect.
47.context: NodeContext: this is thick with meaning. He's subtley admonishing you for doublecrossing the tieflings.

73.speaker: Volo
73.text: But rest assured that your story is in safe hands. Volothamp Geddarm knows exactly what you are.
73.context: NodeContext: A hint of distaste to his usual enthusiasm, but not enough to cause overt offense.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: I didn't mean for any of this to happen.

28.speaker: Volo
28.text: Of course you didn't. History is but a series of accidents, after all, both happy and heinous.

56.speaker: Volo
56.text: But I daresay you're committed now, my friend. So chin up, look around, and remember your role, hm?
56.context: NodeContext: With an edge. Volo is encouraging you but he also thinks you're a war criminal.

46.speaker: Volo
46.text: That way, perhaps we'll both survive the night.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: Give me your notes. I'll decide what you write.

81.speaker: Volo
81.text: I appreciate your editorial instincts, but Deneir himself does not get a peek at my early drafts.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: And the goblins? Should I tell them what you're writing?

14.speaker: Volo
14.text: Ah, well - no need to involve your guests, I should think.

5.speaker: Volo
5.text: Here - you can keep that copy. The details are very much burned into my memory.
5.context: CinematicNodeContext: Handing us his notes from his inventory (off-screen)

29.speaker: Player
29.text: Maybe I'll keep you in this cage for good.

16.speaker: Volo
16.text: ...Perhaps I spoke in haste. Your insights would, of course, be most welcome.

94.speaker: Volo
94.text: Should my writing favour facts over form, it is only to keep pace with events.

95.speaker: Volo
95.text: You have been quite busy, after all.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: You make that sound like a threat.

20.speaker: Volo
20.text: I am simply saying that you are a creature of ambition. Drive. Intent.

90.speaker: Volo
90.text: Fear not! I am content - and quite forgotten - where I am. Better in a cell than in a stew, what?

36.speaker: Volo
36.text: But I'd rather talk about you. If I'm to write an account of the battle, I'll need details while they're still sticky.

103.speaker: Volo
103.text: NO! I mean to say - I am quite content behind bars. A precautionary measure, you understand.

26.speaker: Volo
26.text: I can't rightly document your deeds from the bottom of a goblin cookpot, after all. Ha ha.

68.speaker: Volo
68.text: Aha, there you are! Come now, settle in.

72.speaker: Volo
72.text: I do hope you have partaken of something bracing? This may well take us all night.

102.speaker: Volo
102.text: That ballad was but a crude preview, a frame without its crowning jewel - your nom de guerre.

107.speaker: Volo
107.text: But I am engaged in celebration of the purest form - commemoration.

67.speaker: Volo
67.text: If we are to write your legend in the stars, then we must first give you a name.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: I have other things to do.

53.speaker: Volo
53.text: The very heart of my dilemma! You are the do-er of deeds, I the mere chronicler.

31.speaker: Volo
31.text: But how am I to ensure your most-deserved renown without a suitably thrilling title?

44.speaker: Volo
44.text: Something iconic, but not too much of a mouthful. We don't want to exclude the common-folk, after all. I intend this tale to enrapture all.

27.speaker: Volo
27.text: A wonderful one indeed - but your deeds loom larger than life now, my friend. You simply must have a title to match.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: I get it. Something flashy and made up, like 'Volothamp Geddarm'.

100.speaker: Volo
100.text: Exac-tly wrong, my friend! I urge you to leave the fact-finding to experts, hmm?
100.context: NodeContext: He was about ot say 'Exactly!' and confirm the player's claim, but hten remembered he should NOT reveal that to the player and tries to backpedal.

83.speaker: Volo
83.text: Now, back to your revels. I have some details of your victory to rearrange.

61.speaker: Volo
61.text: 'Grovekeeper'? Are you a gardener? We aim to cultivate mystery, not... shrubbery.

7.speaker: Volo
7.text: No, your actions in the grove were most heroic, but I am afraid this a matter of style, not sentiment.

76.speaker: Volo
76.text: Back to the revelry with you! I'll give the matter some thought in small council.

25.speaker: Player
25.text: 'Goblinsbane' has a nice ring to it.

77.speaker: Volo
77.text: Not to meddle in your side of this partnership, but slaying goblins is not exactly the stuff of legends, is it?

37.speaker: Volo
37.text: After all, I'm quite certain I once saw one expire from the strain of spelling his own name.

39.speaker: Volo
39.text: No, I'm afraid that won't do. You shall simply have to go out and slay something decidedly more dramatic.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: I didn't ask anyone to write my story.

86.speaker: Volo
86.text: And do you think Volothamp Geddarm got where he did by waiting to be asked?

38.speaker: Volo
38.text: No, no - it is for you to slay the dragons, and for me to worry about the accolades.

24.speaker: Volo
24.text: ...Actually slaying a dragon would prove quite helpful, mind.

52.speaker: Volo
52.text: Far too much - this is the very problem. If you could set aside your many triumphs, carry out one defining act...

15.speaker: Volo
15.text: Not to belittle your achievements to date, of course! But besting a dragon, a giant, a god perhaps... hmm.

8.speaker: Volo
8.text: I must deliberate. Go - enjoy your evening! I shall have work for you in the days to come.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Don't you have anything of actual worth to work on?

12.speaker: Volo
12.text: 'Worth'? Volothamp Geddarm takes the matters of names most seriously.

65.speaker: Volo
65.text: And he has an arsenal of choice names for those who don't.

58.speaker: Volo
58.text: Back to your revelry, then - when I have crafted your legend for you, no doubt you shall hear of it.

93.speaker: Volo
93.text: Aha, there you are! Come now, settle in.

66.speaker: Volo
66.text: If you are to repay what you owe, then there is no time to waste. Start at the beginning.
66.context: NodeContext: Getting on with business, not taking time for us to catch up (we have no idea who this man is)

97.speaker: Volo
97.text: Volothamp Geddarm - realm-renowned author, auteur, and tastemaker.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: I don't remember inviting you to my camp.

19.speaker: Volo
19.text: And yet I found it nonetheless. Such is the nature of Volothamp Geddarm, author and interrogator of mysteries.

89.speaker: Volo
89.text: My next piece was meant to be an exposé on the local goblins and their 'Absolute'.

109.speaker: Volo
109.text: They're quite dead now, as you know. Too dead to provide a single meaningful quote.
109.context: NodeContext: he's put out by this

79.speaker: Volo
79.text: You stole a story from me. Courtesy demands I get yours in return.
79.context: NodeContext: As if repeating a grave rule of his profession that should be self-evident to anyone.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: What I owe? What are you talking about?

63.speaker: Volo
63.text: Ye gods, then let us add ignorance to your list of crimes. I am Volothamp Geddarm, realm-renowned author, auteur, and tastemaker.

108.speaker: Volo
108.text: Away and have your fun! I have a myth to make.
